comment: An interesting position. Black's normal strategy would be to storm forwards on the King side with his mobile pawns, but the fact that White's KP is on e2 rather then e4 makes it more difficult for Black to fix on a target. White's normal plan would be to launch a Queen side advance with b2-b4, c4-c5 etc. breaking into Black's camp at the sensitive point c7. However, the absence of White's KP from e4 also exerts an influence over White's plan of campaign in that (after c4-c5) is QP will be deprived of much of his support. In such strategically complex position Numzowitsch excelled. Now many of his original ideas have been absorbed into master tecnique or incorporated into "openings theory".
reasoning: The comment explains the mistake by highlighting the typical strategic plan for Black and how the absence of White's King Pawn on e4 influences Black's approach, as well as how White should adapt their plan due to the missing pawn.

comment: This temporary sacrifice of a pawn looks most promising since it exposes a number of weaknesses in the Black position. However, with this move White is walking straight into a combinative ambush; it could be said that he started out on the ambush trail when he was lured into a Queen side advance (with gain of tempo) by 15...Nc5, but what other choice did White have? Black holds the initiative on the King wing so the only alternative to Queen side activity would be passive defence. Attractive though its execution might appear Nimzowitsch had prepared so efficiently for the possibility of a White Queen side advance that the whole plan of carrying it through could be classed as a collective error.
reasoning: This comment thoroughly explains the mistake made by the player, as it provides a detailed analysis of the consequences of the move, referring to the potential weaknesses and the overall strategic misstep.

comment: "White seems to be in the ascendant but Black has not been marking time. In fact he has been engaged in the accumulation of attacking energy (QR file, h6-d2 diagonal, mobile pawn mass, etc.) and now emerges with a series of noxious blows which had completely escaped White's attention. We might add, by the way, that without Black's cooperation (the partly superfluous and partly provocatory Nc5) White would scarcely ever have been able to arrange his break-through with pawn-c5. (Nimzowitsch)
reasoning: The comment explains that White overlooked Black's accumulating attacking energy, leading to a decisive breakthrough with pawn-c5, as described by Nimzowitsch.
